learning_outcomes.description: List and summarise the basic properties of a selection of clinically relevant microorganisms, and explain how these affect dosage form design and development of drugs used in the treatment or prophylaxis of infection

Identify the properties of infectious agents of relevance to the pharmaceutical industry and pharmacy practice, and apply this knowledge to the selection of antibiotics, disinfectants and sterilisation practices.
Apply knowledge relating to the fundamentals of the production of antibiotic and non-antibiotic antimicrobial products as well as sterile pharmaceutical products.
Outline the properties and processes involved in sterilisation and disinfection methods for pharmaceutical and medical products
List and summarise the principles involved in the design and manufacture of vaccines as well as other pharmaceutical products involving the use of microbes

Apply knowledge of microbes, transmission methods and infectious diseases to the design and implementation of policies and procedures relating to Occupational Health and Safety as well as Public Health.
Recognise and evaluate key structure activity relationships for selected drugs used in the treatment or prophylaxis of infections
Identify important aspects of drug development for drugs used in the treatment or prophylaxis of infections and cancer

assessments.task_description:
Three quizzes examine knowledge of the material covered in the first self-directed learning (SDL) module and in the practical classes. Each quiz consists of 10 automatically marked questions. The questions will be randomly drawn from a pool of questions for each quiz, so each quiz attempt may contain questions different from those used in a previous attempt. Two attempts per quiz are permitted, with higher mark used for grade calculations.

QUIZ 1 will be based on the self-directed learning (SDL1) occurring in Week 1 to test knowledge gained from completing the UQ extend module and self-directed learning.

QUIZ 2 will be based on Practical Schedule 1 (i.e. 1a and 1 b) and comprises 10 automatically marked questions (e.g. MCQ, drag and drop, etc.) to test the knowledge gained from the practicals and as part of self-directed learning.

QUIZ 3 will be based on Practical Schedule 2 (i.e. 2a and 2b) and comprises 10 automatically marked questions (e.g. MCQ, drag and drop, etc.) to test the knowledge gained from the practicals and as part of self-directed learning.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

assessments.task_description:
The end-of-semester written examination will be based on all aspects of the course, including material covered in practical classes, lectures and self-directed learning (SDL) modules. You will be required to bring a laptop to use for the examination.

The exam will be undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform (as will any deferred or supplementary written exams). Go to the Inspera Assessment Information page link to navigate to the Library Services web page which provides further information on: how to access Inspera, on-campus invigilated exams in Inspera, device requirements, familiarisation opportunities, submitting assessment and access to the Student Laptop Scheme and short-term laptop-loans.

This assessment task is an in-person, invigilated Inspera examination. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct
